source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Oxide thicknesses were measured by metallography that indicated that oxidation was enhanced by pressure over this temperature range.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: The deleterious effect increased with temperature up to 900°C where the oxide thicknesses were up to five times greater than expected from atmospheric pressure data.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Where breakaway oxidation occurred, the local oxide thicknesses were up to a factor of seven greater than predicted.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: At 1000°C, the effect was less pronounced than at 900°C, with maximum enhancement factors of around two.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: At 800°C, the enhancement saturated around 15.2 MPa, when further increases in pressure to above normal pressurized water reactor (PWR) operating pressure had no further noticeable effect.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: lengths of Zircaloy-4 were heated to 750 to 1000°C in flowing steam at pressures up to 18.6 MPa.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: At temperatures above about 1000°C in unlimited steam, and where the oxide film is adherent, the reaction is believed to be controlled by diffusion of oxygen anions through the anion-deficient zirconia structure

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: At temperatures below the alpha to alpha + beta transus (about 820°C for Zircaloy-4)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Above the transus temperature, a basically three-layer structure is formed; the outer layer of zirconia, an intermediate layer of alpha-phase zirconium that is stabilized by a high concentration of dissolved oxygen, and an inner layer of beta-phase zirconium into which a smaller concentration of oxygen has diffused.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Above 1050°C, the kinetics of oxide and oxygen-stabilized alpha layer growth are well described by the parabolic rate laws expected from diffusion theory

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: During a test, the pressure could typically be maintained within 0.14 MPa (20 psi) of the intended value

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: For a test between atmospheric pressure and 11.7 MPa, the temperature could be controlled to ±2°C

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: at 18.6 MPa, the temperature was typically held within ±5°C of the target

evidence_span: 0.8 μm at 750°C, 1.2 μm at 800°C, 2.8 μm at 900°C, and 2.9 μm at 1000°C

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk3
evidence_span: The same batch of Zircaloy-4 as used for these tests has been used previously [7] to model oxidation behavior between 700 and 1300°C in atmospheric pressure steam.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk3
evidence_span: The test matrix involved oxidizing specimens at temperatures between 750 and 1000°C in flowing steam at pressures up to 18.6 MPa.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk3
evidence_span: The maximum test duration was 2500 s at the test temperature.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk3
evidence_span: At 750°C (Fig. 2), only one test was performed, of 300 s duration at 11.7 MPa

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk3
evidence_span: the oxide thickness was greater than predicted from Refs 6 and 7 but not significantly so when possible errors are considered.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk3
evidence_span: at 800°C, the test matrix was more extensive and in each case the amount of oxide present was consistently higher than predicted (Fig. 3), by factors of between three and five (five and eight versus the Leistikow et al. data).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk3
evidence_span: for those pressures used in the tests (11.7 MPa or greater), increasing the test pressure did not appear to alter significantly the amount of enhancement, indicating that the accelerating effect of pressure may have saturated.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk3
evidence_span: The oxidation process appeared to follow normal cubic kinetics, at least up to 1000 s.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: All the others had a nonuniform layered structure following initial polishing that, with the exception of the specimens where breakaway had occurred, was triplex in nature with a thin uniform outer oxide and inner duplex inhomogeneous layer

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: The two specimens with breakaway oxidation were found to have four distinct layers in the oxide

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: At $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ , the two specimens with the thickest oxides had a triplex oxide structure and a bright outer band under polarized light

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: The other specimen had a uniform oxide and there was no effect of polarized light

evidence_span: At $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ , the measured enhancements are smaller than at the other temperatures, indicating that the effect of pressure may be declining with further increases in temperature

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: Zircaloy tubing used for nuclear fuel cladding in light water reactors is highly anisotropic due to the hexagonal crystal structure of zirconium at temperatures below approximately 800°C.
process_step: fabrication process using pilgering and intermediate annealing

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: During the normal fabrication process using pilgering and intermediate annealing, the crystallographic planes in the majority of grains become oriented so that the majority of the basal poles lie in the radial-circumferential plane of the cladding with the highest density of basal poles oriented at plus and minus 30° to 40° from the radial direction.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: Plastic deformation of the cladding can be defined by the R and P factors that are the circumferential/radial and axial/radial contractile strain ratios under uniaxial deformation along the axial and circumferential direction, respectively.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: Plastic deformation of the cladding can be defined by the R and P factors that are the circumferential/radial and axial/radial contractile strain ratios under uniaxial deformation along the axial and circumferential direction, respectively.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: In a boiling water reactor (BWR) fuel assembly, most fuel rods have a hoop stress to axial stress ratio of about 2:1.
property_name: hoop stress to axial stress ratio

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: Laboratory tensile and creep tests at several temperatures have been performed on five types of cladding to determine if a short-term test could be used to obtain R values representative of the in-reactor values.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: For standard Zircaloy-2 cladding that was examined in-reactor, a good correlation with the in-reactor R value was obtained from both tensile and creep tests performed at 382°C.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: For another type of Zircaloy-2 cladding (late beta-quenched (LBQ) cladding), in-reactor deformation performance correlates better with the tensile test results than the creep results.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: The other three types of cladding (Zircaloy-4) with differing textures and prior histories have exhibited significant differences in the R values in the laboratory tests.
